chapter.title: Six consensus statements that help to define LD
chapter.content:
Six consensus statements that help to define LD

Now that we have established a consensus definition of LD, let’s look at our first guiding question.

Guiding Question #1 asks:

What are six consensus statements that help us understand the definition of LD?

In the next part of this lesson, we are going to explore the six consensus statements that help us define LD.

chapter.title: Overview of the six consensus statements
chapter.content:
Overview of the six consensus statements

Let’s first take a look at all six of the consensus statements together, and then we will break them down one by one.

  1. The concept of LD is valid and is supported by strong converging evidence.
  2. LD are neurologically based and intrinsic to the individual.
  3. Individuals with LD show intra-individual differences in skills and abilities.
  4. LD persist across the life span.
  5. LD may occur in combination with other disabling conditions, but they are not due to other conditions.
  6. LD are evident across ethnic, cultural, language, and economic groups.

These six consensus statements are important because they represent what is agreed upon in the field of LD.

chapter.title: Research supports the existence of LD
chapter.content:
Research supports the existence of LD

Let’s begin with the first statement. “The concept of LD is valid and is supported by strong converging evidence.”

There is a strong evidence base supporting the existence of LD. This evidence is based on two types of research:

  • brain function research; and
  • educational intervention research.

chapter.title: Brain function research shows differences in individuals with LD
chapter.content:
Brain function research shows differences in individuals with LD

Some research focuses on brain function. Studies using functional MRI technology reveal differences in brain functioning between individuals with and without characteristics associated with LD.

chapter.title: Education intervention research focuses on pre-K-12 education
chapter.content:
Education intervention research focuses on pre-K-12 education

The other type of research base is from education intervention studies, which consistently show that there is a group of individuals who struggle with learning despite powerful interventions. This research focuses on pre-K-12 education. Children with LD are the largest group of individuals served by special education, constituting almost 50 percent of students with disabilities and more than 5 percent of the total school-aged population.

chapter.title: LD are not readily apparent
chapter.content:
LD are not readily apparent

One reason this consensus statement comes first is that LD are “hidden,” which makes them difficult to identify, understand and accept as a real disability. For example, a person who has great reading difficulty will appear normal until asked to read independently, when the hidden disability becomes apparent. This is in contrast to someone with a physical disability that is apparent from the moment we meet the person. In this case, the associated limitations are more easily understood.
